r:PublisherName.r:String: Institute for Social & Economic Research, University of Essex

r:Copyright.r:String: Copyright Institute for Social & Economic Research, University of Essex. All rights reserved.

r:Abstract.r:Content: Understanding Society: The UK Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) studies 21st century UK life and how it is changing. It captures important information every year about the social and economic circumstances, attitudes, behaviours and health of people living in thousands of UK households. Information from the longitudinal survey is primarily used by academics, researchers and policy makers in their work, but the findings are of interest to a much wider group of people including those working in the third sector, health practitioners, business, the media and the general public. Interviews began in 2009 with eligible members of nearly 32,000 selected households invited to take part. Adults are interviewed and 10-15 year-olds fill in a paper self-completion questionnaire. New people join the study as they join the households of existing members, and if members leave their households, all adult members of their new household are interviewed. In 2010-11, some 20,000 participants aged over 16 also received nurse visits and provided a blood sample and some basic physical measurements (height, weight, blood pressure, grip strength). Data collection is annual, but each wave takes place over a two year period, with the second year of one wave overlapping the first year of the subsequent wave (so wave 1 took place between 2009 and 2011, wave 2 between 2010 and 2012, and so forth). A further 8,000 households from the British Household Panel Survey (see below) were invited to join at wave 2. An additional 1,500 UK households are interviewed for the Innovation Panel, a separate annual survey which is used by researchers as a test bed for new ways of collecting data or exploring new topics before they become part of the main survey. UKHLS also has an ethnicity strand, with boost samples to ensure the study had at least 1,000 adults from the five main ethnicity groups in the UK. There are also extra questions asked each year of particular relevance to ethnic groups. In 2015, a further immigrant and ethnic boost sample was added to the study. Study website: https://www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: The ESRC provides funding and support for research and training in the social sciences. It is the UK's largest organisation for funding research on economic and social issues. The ESRC is part of UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) which is a non-departmental public body (NDPB) funded by the UK government (Economic and Social Research Council, n.d.).

OrganizationName.r:String: UK Department for Work and Pensions

r:Description.r:Content: The DWP is a department of the UK government responsible for welfare and pension policy. It was formed in 2001 from the Department of Social Security, absorbing the employment functions which had previously been the responsibility of the Department for Education and Employment (Department for Work and Pensions, n.d.).

The DfT is a department of the UK government responsible for the English transport network and a limited number of transport matters in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland that have not been devolved (Department for Transport, n.d.).

OrganizationName.r:String: UK Department for Culture, Media and Sport

r:Description.r:Content: The DCMS is a department of the UK government, with responsibility for culture and sport in England, the building of a Digital Economy, and some aspects of the media throughout the whole UK, such as broadcasting and internet (Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, n.d.).

OrganizationName.r:String: UK Department for Communities and Local Government

r:Description.r:Content: The DCLG was a department of the UK government, between 2006 and 2017 with a remit to promote community cohesion and equality, as well as responsibility for housing, urban regeneration, planning and local government. The department was renamed the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government (MHCLG) in 2018 (Department for Communities and Local Government, n.d.).

The DoH was a department of the UK government established in 1988, which was previously part of the Department of Health and Social Security. The Department of Health was renamed the Department of Health and Social Care in 2018 which is responsible for government policy on health and adult social care matters in England (Department of Health, n.d.).

The Scottish Government is the executive in Scotland for areas of public policy which are not reserved. The government was established in 1999 as the Scottish Executive under the Scotland Act 1998 (The Scottish Government, n.d.).
The Welsh Assembly Government was renamed Welsh Government under the Wales Act 2014. The Welsh government is the devolved executive of Wales (Welsh Government, n.d.).
The Northern Ireland Executive is the devolved government of Northern Ireland, an administrative branch of the legislature – the Northern Ireland Assembly (Northern Ireland Executive, n.d.).

OrganizationName.r:String: UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

r:Description.r:Content: Defra is a department of the UK government responsible for environmental protection, food production and standards, agriculture, fisheries and rural communities in the UK and Northern Ireland. It was formed in 2001, when the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAFF) was merged with part of the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) and with a small part of the Home Office (Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, n.d.).
The FSA is a non-ministerial government department of the UK. It is responsible for protecting public health in relation to food in England, Wales and Northern Ireland (Food Standards Agency, n.d.).
UK residential population in 2009-10

r:PublisherName.r:String: Institute for Social & Economic Research, University of Essex

r:Abstract.r:Content: This is the first wave of data collection for Understanding Society: The UK Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) studies 21st century UK life and how it is changing. It captures important information every year about the social and economic circumstances, attitudes, behaviours and health of people living in thousands of UK households. Information from the longitudinal survey is primarily used by academics, researchers and policy makers in their work, but the findings are of interest to a much wider group of people including those working in the third sector, health practitioners, business, the media and the general public. Interviews began in 2009 with eligible members of nearly 32,000 selected households invited to take part. Adults are interviewed and 10-15 year-olds fill in a paper self-completion questionnaire. Data collection is annual, but each wave takes place over a two year period. UKHLS also has an ethnicity strand, with boost samples to ensure the study had at least 1,000 adults from the five main ethnicity groups in the UK. There are also extra questions asked each year of particular relevance to ethnic groups. Study website: https://www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Face-to-face computer-assisted personal interviewing.

OrganizationName.r:String: Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency

r:Description.r:Content: The NISRA is an executive agency within the Department of Finance in Northern Ireland. The organisation is responsible for the collection and publication of statistics related to the economy, population and society of Northern Ireland. It is responsible for conducting the decennial census and incorporates the General Register Office (GRO) for Northern Ireland which is responsible for the registration of births, marriages, civil partnerships and deaths (Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency, n.d.).

The National Centre for Social Research is a registered charity trading as NatCen Social Research and is the largest independent social research institute in the UK. The research charity was founded in 1969 with the aim of carrying out rigorous social policy research to improve society (National Centre for Social Research, n.d.).
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
UK residential population in 2009-10

r:Abstract.r:Content: This is the second wave of data collection for Understanding Society: The UK Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) studies 21st century UK life and how it is changing. It captures important information every year about the social and economic circumstances, attitudes, behaviours and health of people living in thousands of UK households. Information from the longitudinal survey is primarily used by academics, researchers and policy makers in their work, but the findings are of interest to a much wider group of people including those working in the third sector, health practitioners, business, the media and the general public. Interviews began in 2010 with eligible members of productive households from wave 1 invited to take part. Adults are interviewed and 10-15 year-olds fill in a paper self-completion questionnaire. Data collection is annual, but each wave takes place over a two year period. UKHLS also has an ethnicity strand, with boost samples to ensure the study had at least 1,000 adults from the five main ethnicity groups in the UK. There are also extra questions asked each year of particular relevance to ethnic groups. Study website: https://www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/

r:Abstract.r:Content: This is the fourth wave of data collection for Understanding Society: The UK Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) studies 21st century UK life and how it is changing. It captures important information every year about the social and economic circumstances, attitudes, behaviours and health of people living in thousands of UK households. Information from the longitudinal survey is primarily used by academics, researchers and policy makers in their work, but the findings are of interest to a much wider group of people including those working in the third sector, health practitioners, business, the media and the general public. Interviews began in 2012 with eligible members of households from earlier waves invited to take part. Adults are interviewed and 10-15 year-olds fill in a paper self-completion questionnaire. Data collection is annual, but each wave takes place over a two year period. UKHLS also has an ethnicity strand, with boost samples to ensure the study had at least 1,000 adults from the five main ethnicity groups in the UK. There are also extra questions asked each year of particular relevance to ethnic groups. Study website: https://www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/

r:Abstract.r:Content: This is the sixth wave of data collection for Understanding Society: The UK Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) studies 21st century UK life and how it is changing. It captures important information every year about the social and economic circumstances, attitudes, behaviours and health of people living in thousands of UK households. Information from the longitudinal survey is primarily used by academics, researchers and policy makers in their work, but the findings are of interest to a much wider group of people including those working in the third sector, health practitioners, business, the media and the general public. r:Description.r:Content: Face-to-face computer-assisted personal interviewing.
Millward Brown Ulster was a market research and public opinion polling company established in 2002. In 2008 it was acquired by Kantar TNS (Kantar TNS, n.d.).

TNS-BMRB which is now known as Kantar Public UK was established in 1933 and is now part of global Kantar Public network. It is a global market research and market information group (Kantar TNS, n.d.).
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
UK residential population in 2014-15

r:PublisherName.r:String: Institute for Social & Economic Research, University of Essex

r:Abstract.r:Content: The Understanding Society COVID-19 Study 2020 is a monthly survey of households in the UK. The aim of the study is to enable research on the socio-economic and health consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in the short and long term. Participants complete one survey a month, which includes core content designed to track changes, alongside variable content adapted each month as the coronavirus situation develops. This is the third of the monthly surveys which started in April 2020 and complements the annual interviews of the Understanding Society study. Participants from the main Understanding Society sample were asked to complete a short web-survey. The survey covered; the changing impact of the pandemic on the welfare of UK individuals, families and wider communities. A telephone interview was offered to respondents who wish to take part but who live in a household where no-one is a regular internet user. Fieldwork for the telephone interviews took place between late-May to early-June 2020.  Study website: www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/topic/covid-19

r:LowestLevelReference.r:LevelName: EUL: Government Office Region, Special License: Lower Layer Super Output Areas, Secure Access: National Grid Reference

r:Description.r:Content: Computer-assisted web interviewing (CAWI). Data are collected using a web questionnaire, produced with a program for creating web surveys.

Ipsos MORI is a market research company in the UK. It was formed by a merger of Ipsos UK and MORI in 2005. Ipsos MORI conduct surveys for a wide range of major organisations as well as other market research agencies (Ipsos_MORI).

Kantar Public works with clients in government, the public sector, global institutions, NGOs and commercial businesses to advise in the delivery of public policy, public services and public communications.
The Health Foundation is a registered grant-making charity funded by an £1bn endowment. It aims to bring about better health and health care for people in the UK (The Health Foundation, n.d.).
UK residential population in 2020 who have participated in at least one of the last two waves of Understanding Society data collection.
